</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	n/m&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;not meaningful
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	expense of $511.1&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $120.6&nbsp;million or 30.9% from
	$390.5&nbsp;million in 2015. The variances in the individual
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	expense items are further explained in the following paragraphs with an overriding theme of the increases for several line items
	related to the expanded operations from the METR acquisition and BofA and Fifth Third branch purchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Salaries and employee benefits of
	$239.8&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $37.7&nbsp;million or 18.7% from $202.1&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to employees added in conjunction with the aforementioned acquisitions and heightened regulatory compliance costs, combined with new
	hires, merit increases and higher medical insurance costs in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net occupancy and equipment expense of $78.1&nbsp;million for 2016 increased
	$12.6&nbsp;million or 19.2% from $65.5&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily resulting from the acquisitions, combined with additional costs associated with our continued investment in new technology. The increased technology costs include upgrades to
	meet customer needs via the utilization of electronic delivery channels, such as online and mobile banking, investment in infrastructure to support our larger company and expenditures to meet regulatory requirements. These increases were partially
	offset by lower costs attributable to a mild winter season in the early part of 2016, compared to the same period of 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amortization of intangibles
	expense of $11.2&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $2.9&nbsp;million or 35.0% from $8.3&nbsp;million in 2015, due to the additional core deposit intangibles added as a result of the METR acquisition and BofA and Fifth Third branch purchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	54
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage55"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Outside services expense of $43.7&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $9.0&nbsp;million or 26.0% from
	$34.7&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to an increase of $5.1&nbsp;million in services, such as reporting and monitoring, shredding, printing and filing, that are provided by others. Additionally, data processing services, check card expenses and
	licenses, fees and dues increased $1.3&nbsp;million, $0.9&nbsp;million and $0.7&nbsp;million, respectively. These increases were all primarily due to additional costs associated with the recent acquisitions and were partially offset by a decrease of
	$0.8&nbsp;million decrease in consulting fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	FDIC insurance of $19.2&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $6.3&nbsp;million or 49.0% from $12.9&nbsp;million
	in 2015, primarily due to a higher assessment base due to merger and acquisition activity. Additionally, we are now paying a surcharge for banks with over $10&nbsp;billion in assets and a higher level due to increased classified assets relating to
	the METR acquisition. The surcharge is assessed on all assets over $10&nbsp;billion at the rate of 4.5 basis points annualized, which resulted in additional expense in the last half of 2016 of $2.2&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Supplies expense of $10.8&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $2.8&nbsp;million or 34.4% from $8.1&nbsp;million in 2015, as we recognized additional costs
	associated with the recent acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Bank shares and franchise taxes expense of $8.9&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $0.8&nbsp;million or 9.8% from
	$8.1&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to a higher assessment base resulting from enhanced capital levels at FNBPA in conjunction with the recent acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Telephone expense of $7.2&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $0.9&nbsp;million or 14.8% from $6.2&nbsp;million in 2015, as we recognized additional costs
	associated with the recent acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Advertising and promotional expense of $10.1&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $1.7&nbsp;million or 20.8% from
	$8.4&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to higher expenses associated with the recent acquisitions, combined with additional costs associated with promotional efforts to support further expansion in the Cleveland, Ohio and Baltimore, Maryland
	metropolitan markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Loan-related expense of $8.2&nbsp;million for 2016 increased $2.0&nbsp;million or 32.6% from $6.2&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily
	due to higher appraisal fees and collection expenses, partially offset by lower filing fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	OREO expense of $5.2&nbsp;million for 2016 increased
	$0.5&nbsp;million or 11.1% from $4.6&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily due to write-downs to permit the sale of certain properties during the year, combined with updated valuations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We recorded $37.4 and $3.0&nbsp;million in merger-related costs in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The 2016 costs were related to the METR acquisition, the Fifth
	Third branch purchase and the pending YDKN acquisition, while the 2015 costs were associated with the METR acquisition and BofA branch purchase. These costs are specific to each individual transaction, and may vary significantly based on the size
	and complexity of the transaction. The costs for 2015 and 2016 are summarized in the following table:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

	expense was $31.2&nbsp;million and $22.4&nbsp;million for 2016 and
	2015, respectively. During 2016, we incurred a $2.6&nbsp;million impairment charge on acquired other assets relating to low income housing projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Additionally, during 2016, business development expenses increased $1.0&nbsp;million and postage expense increased $0.7&nbsp;million, both primarily due to the recent acquisitions. Also, other
	miscellaneous losses increased $2.2&nbsp;million over this same period, primarily due to higher credit card disputes and fraud losses given our expanded size and geographic footprint.
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our income tax expense for 2016 increased $5.5&nbsp;million or 7.9% from 2015. The effective tax rate was 30.6% for 2016
	compared to 30.5% for 2015. Both periods&#146; tax rates are lower than the 35% federal statutory tax rate due to the tax benefits primarily resulting from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	income on investments and loans, tax
	credits and income from BOLI.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 Compared to Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Refer to the previous section of this Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis for tables which reflect a comparison of the years ended 2015 versus 2014.
	Certain significant changes for the years ended 2015 versus 2014 are discussed in the paragraphs that follow.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net income available to common stockholders
	for 2015 was $151.6&nbsp;million or $0.86 per diluted common share, compared to net income available to common stockholders for 2014 of $135.7&nbsp;million or $0.80 per diluted common share. The results for 2015 included $3.0&nbsp;million in merger
	costs and reflect costs and benefits associated with the BofA branch purchase that closed on September&nbsp;18, 2015, combined with costs associated with the METR acquisition that closed on February&nbsp;13, 2016. The results for 2014 included
	$9.6&nbsp;million in merger costs and reflect the OBA, BCSB and PVF acquisitions that closed on September&nbsp;19, 2014, February&nbsp;15, 2014 and October&nbsp;12, 2013, respectively. Average diluted common shares outstanding increased
	7.3&nbsp;million shares or 4.3% to 176.3&nbsp;million shares for 2015, primarily as a result of the full-year effect of the previously-mentioned acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our return on average equity was 7.70% and our return on average assets was 0.96% for 2015, compared to 7.50% and 0.96%, respectively, for 2014. Our return on
	average tangible common equity was 14.46% and our return on average tangible assets was 1.06% for 2015, compared to 14.91% and 1.08%, respectively, for 2014. Average equity was $2.1&nbsp;billion and $1.9&nbsp;billion for 2015 and 2014, respectively,
	while average tangible equity was $1.2&nbsp;billion and $1.1&nbsp;billion, respectively, for those same periods. Average equity for 2015 reflects the full-year impact of the above-mentioned acquisitions that were completed during 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Net Interest Income
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, net interest income, which
	comprised 75.4% of net revenue compared to 74.7% in 2014, was affected by the general level of interest rates, changes in interest rates, the timing of repricing of assets and liabilities, the shape of the yield curve, the level of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans and changes in the amount and mix of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net
	interest income, on an FTE basis, increased $32.7&nbsp;million or 6.9% from $473.2&nbsp;million for 2014 to $505.9&nbsp;million for 2015. Average interest-earning assets increased $1.6&nbsp;billion or 12.4% and average
	interest-
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	56
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	bearing liabilities increased $1.1&nbsp;billion or 10.6% from 2014, due to the acquisitions of OBA and BCSB, combined with organic growth in loans and deposits. Our net interest margin was 3.42%
	for 2015, compared to 3.59% for 2014, as loan yields declined faster than deposit rates primarily as a result of the current low interest rate environment. Accretable yield adjustments added 6 basis points to the net interest margin for both 2015
	and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest income, on an FTE basis, of $554.4&nbsp;million for 2015, increased $38.5&nbsp;million or 7.5% from 2014, primarily due to increased
	interest-earning assets, partially offset by lower yields due to competitive market rates throughout 2015 being less than portfolio yields at the end of 2014. During 2015 and 2014, we recognized a benefit of $5.0&nbsp;million and $6.6&nbsp;million,
	respectively, in accretable yield adjustments on acquired loans. The increase in interest-earning assets was primarily driven by a $1.3&nbsp;billion or 12.4% increase in average loans, including $1.0&nbsp;billion or 9.7% of organic growth, which
	reflects the benefit of our expanded banking footprint and successful sales management. The yield on interest-earning assets decreased 17 basis points from 3.92% for 2014 to 3.75% for 2015, reflecting the decreases in market interest rates,
	competitive pressures and the above-mentioned changes in accretable yield adjustments on acquired loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Interest expense of $48.6&nbsp;million for 2015
	increased $5.9&nbsp;million or 13.8% from 2014 due to growth in interest-bearing liabilities. The rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities increased 1 basis point to 0.42% for 2015, compared to 0.41% for 2014, reflecting changes in interest rates
	and the effect of the subordinated debt borrowed in October 2015, partially offset by a favorable shift in deposit mix to lower-cost transaction deposits. The growth in average interest-bearing liabilities was primarily attributable to growth in
	average interest-bearing deposits, which increased $0.7&nbsp;billion or 8.5%, including $0.5&nbsp;billion or 5.0% of organic growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for
	Credit Losses
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The provision for credit losses of $40.4&nbsp;million during 2015 increased $1.8&nbsp;million from 2014, primarily due to an increase
	of $7.4&nbsp;million in the provision for the originated portfolio supporting loan growth, and to a lesser degree, some slight credit migration within the originated commercial portfolio. This was partially offset by a decrease of $5.6&nbsp;million
	in the provision for the acquired portfolio, which resulted from lower acquired net charge-offs and generally more favorable cash flow
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-estimations
</FONT>
	during the year. During 2015, net charge-offs were
	$24.4&nbsp;million, or 0.21% of average loans and leases, compared to $23.5&nbsp;million, or 0.23% of average loans and leases, for 2014. The ratio of the allowance for credit losses to total loans and leases equaled 1.16% and 1.12% at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, reflecting our overall favorable credit quality performance, along with the addition of loans acquired in the BCSB and OBA acquisitions during 2014, which did not carry a corresponding allowance for
	credit losses in accordance with acquired loan accounting rules. For additional information relating to the allowance and provision for credit losses, refer to the Allowance for Credit Losses section of this Management&#146;s Discussion and
	Analysis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Interest
</FONT>
	Income
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	income of $162.4&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $4.1&nbsp;million or 2.6% from $158.3&nbsp;million
	in 2014. The variances in significant individual
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	income items are further explained in the following paragraphs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Service charges on loans and deposits of $70.7&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $2.4&nbsp;million or 3.6% from $68.3&nbsp;million in 2014. Deposit-related
	service charges decreased $0.5&nbsp;million or 1.3% over this period following a nationwide trend as consumers are better managing their accounts to avoid these types of fees. Other service charges and fees increased $3.0&nbsp;million or 10.7% over
	this period, reflecting the impact of organic growth and the expanded customer base due to acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Trust fees of $20.9&nbsp;million for 2015
	increased $1.6&nbsp;million or 8.1% from $19.4&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily driven by strong organic growth activity, geographic expansion and improved market conditions. The market value of assets under management increased $194.9&nbsp;million
	or 5.5% to $3.7&nbsp;billion from December&nbsp;31, 2014 to December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	57
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Insurance commissions and fees of $16.3&nbsp;million for 2015 decreased $0.5&nbsp;million or 2.9% from
	$16.8&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to reduced contingent fee income resulting from increases in claims and higher loss ratios during 2015 compared to 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Securities commissions of $13.6&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $2.2&nbsp;million or 19.1% from $11.5&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to positive results
	from initiatives generating new customer relationships, combined with increased volume, geographic expansion and improved market conditions. Partially offsetting these increases were the costs associated with a securities system conversion, combined
	with the impact of severe weather conditions throughout FNB&#146;s market area in the first half of 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Swap fee income of $9.5&nbsp;million for 2015
	increased $3.7&nbsp;million or 65.0% from $5.7&nbsp;million in 2014, as we recorded more in fees earned through our commercial loan interest rate swap program, reflecting strong commercial loan growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net securities gains were $0.8&nbsp;million and $11.7&nbsp;million for 2015 and 2014, respectively. During 2014, FNB strategically sold our entire portfolio
	of pooled TPS for net proceeds of $51.5&nbsp;million and a gain of $13.8&nbsp;million. Of the 23 pooled securities sold, one was determined to be a disallowed investment under the Volcker Rule of the Dodd-Frank Act, and as such, was required to be
	disposed of by July 2016. Partially offsetting this gain was a net loss of $2.1&nbsp;million relating to the sale of other securities. By selling these securities, we strengthened the risk profile of our investment portfolio, improved our capital
	levels due to lowered risk-weighted assets and generated capital to support future growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Mortgage banking operations generated income of
	$8.6&nbsp;million and $3.7&nbsp;million for 2015 and 2014, respectively. This increase was primarily due to higher origination volume and successful cross-selling efforts generated from a strengthened mortgage management team and expanded market
	presence. During 2015, we sold $444.7&nbsp;million of residential mortgage loans, compared to $162.7&nbsp;million for 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	income was $13.9&nbsp;million and $13.5&nbsp;million for 2015 and 2014, respectively. During 2015, we recorded $1.7&nbsp;million more in dividends on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-marketable
</FONT>
	equity securities, primarily resulting from a special dividend paid by the FHLB totaling $1.0&nbsp;million. Additionally, we recorded $1.0&nbsp;million more in gains from an equity investment, a
	gain of $0.4&nbsp;million relating to the sale of our ownership interest in a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-banking
</FONT>
	affiliate and a gain of $0.4&nbsp;million relating to the settlement of an insurance benefit. Also during 2015, we
	recognized $0.5&nbsp;million more in gains on the sale of fixed assets, $0.5&nbsp;million more in foreign currency exchange income, $0.4&nbsp;million less in recoveries of impaired loans acquired in previous acquisitions and $0.5&nbsp;million less
	in swap valuation income due to changes in the yield curve. During 2015, we recorded $0.9&nbsp;million in short-term equipment rental income. During 2014, we recognized a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	$2.7&nbsp;million gain from
	an overpayment related to a predecessor bank&#146;s acquisition of another bank prior to becoming part of us and recorded a gain of $0.9&nbsp;million related to the sale of impaired commercial loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Interest
</FONT>
	Expense
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	expense of $390.5&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $11.3&nbsp;million or 3.0% from
	$379.3&nbsp;million in 2014. The variances in the individual
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	expense items are further explained in the following paragraphs with an overriding theme of the expense increases being primarily
	related to the expanded operations from acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Salaries and employee benefits of $202.1&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $7.1&nbsp;million or 3.6%
	from $195.0&nbsp;million in 2014. This increase primarily relates to employees added in conjunction with the acquisitions and heightened regulatory compliance costs, combined with new hires, merit increases and higher medical insurance costs in
	2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Occupancy and equipment expense of $65.5&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $4.0&nbsp;million or 6.5% from $61.5&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily
	resulting from acquisitions, combined with an increase in rental expense relating to the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	58
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pittsburgh headquarters and regional headquarters in Cleveland, Ohio and Baltimore, Maryland. Additionally, our continued focus on new technology, both in meeting customer needs via the
	utilization of electronic delivery channels, such as online and mobile banking, and in meeting the continued regulatory requirements, resulted in an increase of $2.6&nbsp;million in technology-related expense during 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amortization of intangibles expense of $8.3&nbsp;million for 2015 decreased $1.4&nbsp;million or 14.5% from $9.7&nbsp;million in 2014, due to a combination of
	certain intangible assets being completely amortized during 2014 and declining amortization expense on some intangible assets due to accelerated amortization methods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Outside services expense of $34.7&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $1.5&nbsp;million or 4.5% from $33.2&nbsp;million in 2014. During 2015, data processing
	services, security services and other services provided increased $0.5&nbsp;million, $0.4&nbsp;million and $0.3&nbsp;million, respectively, primarily resulting from the OBA and BCSB acquisitions and costs related to compliance with new regulations.
	Additionally, consulting fees increased $0.8&nbsp;million during this same period, as 2014 reflected a refund of previously paid consulting fees, and check card expenses decreased $0.8&nbsp;million as a result of obtaining a new contract with an
	outside party providing processing services.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	FDIC insurance of $12.9&nbsp;million for 2015 decreased $0.4&nbsp;million or 2.8% from $13.3&nbsp;million in
	2014, due to the implementation of certain business strategies to lower our assessment rate along with a refinement of previous estimates related to Basel III requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Supplies expense of $8.1&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $1.0&nbsp;million or 13.6% from $7.1&nbsp;million in 2014, as we recognized additional costs
	associated with the recent acquisitions and recent company-wide conversion to an enhanced internal network platform.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Bank shares and franchise taxes
	expense of $8.1&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $1.2&nbsp;million or 17.0% from $7.0&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to a higher assessment base resulting from enhanced capital levels at FNBPA due to the 2014 acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Telephone expense of $6.2&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $0.5&nbsp;million or 9.2% from $5.7&nbsp;million in 2014, as we recognized additional costs
	associated with the recent acquisitions and an expanded mobile work force.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Advertising and promotional expense of $8.4&nbsp;million for 2015 increased
	$0.6&nbsp;million or 7.3% from $7.8&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to higher expenses associated with the recent acquisitions, as we implemented promotional efforts to support further expansion in the Cleveland, Ohio and the higher cost
	Baltimore, Maryland metropolitan markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Loan-related expense of $6.2&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $1.2&nbsp;million or 24.9% from $4.9&nbsp;million
	in 2014, primarily due to appraisal fees and processing costs incurred for enhanced underwriting standards.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	OREO expense of $4.6&nbsp;million for 2015
	increased slightly from 2014, as we incurred higher levels of write-downs to permit the sale of certain properties in our continuing effort to manage expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We recorded $3.0&nbsp;million in merger-related costs in 2015, primarily associated with the METR acquisition and BofA branch purchase. The detail of these
	costs was previously disclosed.&nbsp;Merger-related costs recorded during 2014 were $9.6&nbsp;million, primarily in conjunction with the OBA and BCSB acquisitions. The merger-related costs for 2014 were comprised of $4.9&nbsp;million in severance
	and other employee benefit costs, $2.8&nbsp;million in professional services, $1.0&nbsp;million in data processing conversion costs, $0.7&nbsp;million in marketing costs and $0.2&nbsp;million in other expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	expense was $22.4&nbsp;million and $20.0&nbsp;million for 2015 and 2014, respectively. During 2015,
	we recognized $0.7&nbsp;million more in other taxes, primarily due to acquisitions and volume increases related to organic growth. In addition, other miscellaneous losses increased $0.3&nbsp;million, primarily due to higher credit card disputes and
	fraud losses. We also recorded $0.6&nbsp;million in costs associated with short-term equipment rental income during 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	59
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our income tax expense of $70.0&nbsp;million for 2015 increased $7.4&nbsp;million or 11.8% from $62.6&nbsp;million in 2014. The effective tax rate was 30.5%
	for 2015 compared to 30.3% for 2014. Both periods&#146; tax rates are lower than the 35% federal statutory tax rate due to the tax benefits primarily resulting from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	income on investments and loans,
	tax credits and income from BOLI.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The December&nbsp;31, 2016 balance sheet includes the METR acquisition and Fifth Third branch purchase mentioned previously.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Lending Activity
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The loan and lease portfolio
	consists principally of loans and leases to individuals and small- and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	medium-sized
</FONT>
	businesses within our primary market area of Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio, Maryland and northern West Virginia. The total
	portfolio also contains consumer finance loans to individuals in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Tennessee and Kentucky, which totaled $184.7&nbsp;million or 1.2% of total loans at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $186.2&nbsp;million or 1.5% of the total
	portfolio at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Due to the relative size of the consumer finance loan portfolio, they are not segregated from other consumer loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	60
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The loans and leases portfolio categories are comprised of the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Commercial real estate includes both owner-occupied and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-owner-occupied
</FONT>
	loans secured by commercial properties.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Commercial and industrial includes loans to businesses that are not secured by real estate.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Commercial leases consist of leases for new or used equipment.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Direct installment is comprised of fixed-rate,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	closed-end
</FONT>
	consumer loans for personal, family or household use, such as home equity loans and automobile loans.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</TD>

	&nbsp;
</TD>

	Residential mortgages consist of conventional and jumbo mortgage loans for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	1-4
</FONT>
	family properties.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="7%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Indirect installment is comprised of loans originated by approved third parties and underwritten by us, primarily automobile loans.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Consumer lines of credit include home equity lines of credit (HELOC) and consumer lines of credit that are either unsecured or secured by collateral other than home equity.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Other is comprised primarily of credit cards, mezzanine loans and student loans.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Additional information
	relating to originated and acquired loans is provided in Note 6, &#147;Loans and Leases&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total loans and leases increased $2.7&nbsp;billion or 22.2% to $14.9&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $12.2&nbsp;billion at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, as we acquired $1.9&nbsp;billion and $97.7&nbsp;million in loans from the METR acquisition and Fifth Third branch purchase, respectively. Additionally, organic growth resulted in an additional increase of $748.1&nbsp;million
	in total loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total loans and leases increased $943.4&nbsp;million or 8.4% to $12.2&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to
	$11.2&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2014, as a result of organic growth, particularly in commercial loans and leases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	36.2% of the commercial real estate loans were owner-occupied, while the remaining 63.8% were
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-owner-occupied,
</FONT>
	compared to 38.1% and 61.9%, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, we had commercial construction loans of $460.0&nbsp;million and $352.3&nbsp;million, respectively, representing 3.1% and 2.9% of total loans and leases, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Within our primary lending footprint, certain industries are more predominant given the geographic location of these lending markets. We strive to maintain a
	diverse commercial loan portfolio by avoiding undue concentrations or exposures to any particular sector, and we actively monitor our commercial loan portfolio to ensure that our industry mix is appropriate and within targeted thresholds Several
	factors are taken into consideration when determining these thresholds, including recent economic and market trends. Over the last
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	61
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage62"></A>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	several quarters, certain borrowers in commodity-based industries have faced challenges related to softer commodity prices, which has led to migration during this time, as these borrowers are
	more sensitive to price movements in these markets.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For additional information relating to lending activity, see Note 6, &#147;Loans and Leases&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated
	Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-Performing
</FONT>
	Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-performing
</FONT>
	loans include
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	troubled debt restructurings (TDRs). Past due loans are reviewed on a monthly basis to identify loans for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	status. We place a loan on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	status and discontinue interest accruals on originated loans generally when principal or interest is due and has remained unpaid for a certain number of days, unless the loan is both well secured and in
	the process of collection. Commercial loans are placed on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	at 90 days, installment loans are placed on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	at 120 days and residential mortgages and
	consumer lines of credit are generally placed on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	at 180 days. When a loan is placed on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	status, all unpaid accrued interest is reversed.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans may not be restored to accrual status until all delinquent principal and interest have been paid and the ultimate ability to collect the remaining principal and interest is reasonably assured. TDRs
	are loans in which the borrower has been granted a concession on the interest rate or the original repayment terms due to financial distress.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-performing
</FONT>
	assets also include debt securities on which OTTI
	has been taken in the current or prior periods that have not been returned to accrual status.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following is a summary of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	assets:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Total

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	62
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	loans and OREO increased $7.6&nbsp;million.
	This reflects an increase of $15.6&nbsp;million in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans, partially offset by decreases of $1.6&nbsp;million and $6.4&nbsp;million in TDRs and OREO, respectively. The increase in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans was primarily attributable to the migration of a few borrowers in the commercial and industrial portfolio that operate largely within commodity-based industries that have faced pricing pressures.
	The decrease in TDRs was primarily attributable to payoffs of commercial credits. Despite the additional OREO properties acquired from METR and Fifth Third, including banking facilities that are no longer in use, OREO decreased, primarily due to the
	sale of several commercial OREO properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	loans and OREO increased
	$0.8&nbsp;million. This reflects an increase of $4.8&nbsp;million in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans, partially offset by decreases of $1.4&nbsp;million and $2.5&nbsp;million in TDRs and OREO, respectively. The increase in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	loans was primarily due to the migration of a single commercial and industrial credit tied to the metals market. The decrease in TDRs was attributed to additional consumer borrowers that met the modified
	terms of their agreements for the required period of time and were returned to performing status. The decrease in OREO was attributed to property sales during 2015 outpacing transfers in, particularly for commercial properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following is a summary of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	loans and leases, by class:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	TDRs are loans whose contractual terms have been modified in a manner that grants a concession to a borrower experiencing
	financial difficulties. TDRs typically result from loss mitigation activities and could include the extension of a maturity date, interest rate reduction, principal forgiveness, deferral or decrease in payments for a period of time and other actions
	intended to minimize the economic loss and to avoid foreclosure or repossession of collateral.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	TDRs that are accruing and performing include loans that
	we can reasonably estimate the timing and amount of the expected cash flows on such loans and for which we expect to fully collect the new carrying value of the loans. TDRs that are accruing and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performing
</FONT>
	are comprised of loans that have not demonstrated a consistent repayment pattern on the modified terms for more than nine months, however it is expected that we will collect all future principal and interest payments. TDRs that are on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-accrual
</FONT>
	are not placed on accruing status until all delinquent principal and interest have been paid and the ultimate ability to collect the remaining principal and interest is reasonably assured. Some loan
	modifications classified as TDRs may not ultimately result in the full collection of principal and interest, as modified, and may result in incremental losses which are factored into the allowance for credit losses estimate. Additional information
	related to our TDRs is included in Note 6, &#147;Loans and Leases&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	63
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage64"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increases in loans and leases 90 days or more past due and accruing in 2016 and 2013 were primarily the result of
	acquisitions. Acquired loans that are 90 days or more past due are considered to be accruing since we can reasonably estimate future cash flows and we expect to fully collect the carrying value of these loans. The acquired loans were discounted and
	marked to fair value with interest income recognized via accretion in accordance with GAAP.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Allowance for Credit Losses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses represents management&#146;s estimate of probable loan losses inherent in the loan portfolio at a specific point in time. This
	estimate includes losses associated with specifically identified loans, as well as estimated probable credit losses inherent in the remainder of the loan portfolio. Additions are made to the allowance for credit losses through both periodic
	provisions charged to income and recoveries of losses previously recorded. Reductions to the allowance for credit losses occur as loans are charged off. Additional information related to our policy for our allowance for credit losses is included in
	the Application of Critical Accounting Policies section of this financial review and in Note 1, &#147;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	65
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following is a summary of changes in the allowance for credit losses related to loans and leases:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses at December&nbsp;31, 2016 increased $16.1&nbsp;million or 11.3% from December&nbsp;31, 2015,
	primarily in support of organic loan growth, credit migration and additional specific reserves of $0.6&nbsp;million. The provision for credit losses for 2016 was $55.8&nbsp;million, covering organic loan growth, net charge-offs of
	$39.7&nbsp;million, which included a $4.0&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	charge-off
</FONT>
	from a single commercial relationship involving a borrower alleged to have falsified documents and financial information over an extended
	period of time, and credit migration.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses at December&nbsp;31, 2015 increased $16.1&nbsp;million or 12.8% from
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 as the provision for credit losses for 2015 of $40.4&nbsp;million exceeded net charge-offs of $24.4&nbsp;million, with the remainder supporting loan growth in the originated portfolio, and some credit migration within the
	commercial and industrial and indirect installment portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	66
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage67"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses at December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased $15.1&nbsp;million or 13.7% from
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 as the provision for credit losses for 2014 of $38.6&nbsp;million exceeded net charge-offs of $23.5&nbsp;million, with the remainder supporting loan growth and incurred losses in the originated and acquired loan portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses at December&nbsp;31, 2013 increased $6.4&nbsp;million or 6.1% from December&nbsp;31, 2012 as the provision for loans
	losses for 2013 of $31.1&nbsp;million exceeded net charge-offs of $24.7&nbsp;million, with the remainder supporting loan growth and incurred losses in the originated and acquired loan portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses at December&nbsp;31, 2012 increased $3.7&nbsp;million or 3.7% from December&nbsp;31, 2011 as the provision for credit losses
	for 2012 of $31.3&nbsp;million exceeded net charge-offs of $27.6&nbsp;million, with the remainder of the provision supporting loan growth and incurred losses in the originated and acquired loan portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following is a summary of the allocation of the allowance for credit losses and the percentage of loans in each category to total loans:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the allowance for credit losses allocated to commercial loans increased to support organic loan growth, as well
	as migration within the commercial and industrial portfolio, which was impacted by the continued softness in the commodity industries, which has adversely impacted certain borrowers that operate in this area. The allowance for credit losses
	allocated to residential mortgages increased during 2016 largely due to organic growth within that portfolio.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, the allowance for credit
	losses allocated to commercial loans and consumer loans (direct installment, indirect installment and consumer lines of credit) increased to support organic loan growth, while a portion of the commercial and industrial and indirect installment
	allowance for credit losses also supported some limited credit migration within those portfolios. The allowance for credit losses allocated to residential mortgages decreased slightly during this same period, which was the result of growth-related
	reserves being more than offset by general improvements in asset quality within that portfolio. The allowance for credit losses allocated to acquired loans decreased during the year as a result of favorable quarterly cash flow
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-estimation
</FONT>
	results and problem credit resolution, with the PVF, ANNB, and Comm Bancorp, Inc. (CBI) portfolios driving the decrease.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2014, the allowance for credit losses allocated to commercial loans, consumer loans and residential mortgages increased to support organic loan growth.
	The allowance for credit losses increased as a result of the growth in each of the loan portfolios noted above and was partially offset by allowance declines as a result of the general improvement in asset quality and charge-offs throughout 2014,
	particularly in the commercial loan portfolios. Furthermore, we expanded the number of modeling segments in 2014, which allowed for a more precise allowance calculation and moderately offset the required allowance as a result of organic loan growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	67
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage68"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The allowance for credit losses allocated to acquired loans increased during the year as a result of the quarterly cash flow
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-estimation
</FONT>
	process,
	moderate builds in a few loan pools and, to a lesser extent, the addition of the BCSB and OBA portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2013, the allowance for credit losses
	allocated to residential mortgages and consumer loans increased to support organic loan growth. Positive asset quality results in the commercial loan portfolio outpaced loan provisions for organic growth, resulting in the allowance for credit losses
	allocated to that portfolio to decrease. The allowance for credit losses related to acquired loans increased during the year primarily as a result of some deterioration in expected cash flows since acquisition in a few small business pools within
	the PVF and CBI portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Investment Activity
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Investment activities serve to enhance net interest income while supporting interest rate sensitivity and liquidity positions. Securities purchased with the
	intent and ability to hold until maturity are categorized as securities held to maturity and carried at amortized cost. All other securities are categorized as securities available for sale and are recorded at fair value. Securities, like loans, are
	subject to similar interest rate and credit risk. In addition, by their nature, securities classified as available for sale are also subject to fair value risks that could negatively affect the level of liquidity available to us, as well as
	stockholders&#146; equity. A change in the value of securities held to maturity could also negatively affect the level of stockholders&#146; equity if there was a decline in the underlying creditworthiness of the issuers and an OTTI is deemed to
	have occurred or if there was a change in our intent and ability to hold the securities to maturity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, securities totaling
	$2.2&nbsp;billion and $2.3&nbsp;billion were classified as available for sale and held to maturity, respectively. During 2016, securities available for sale increased by $601.4&nbsp;million and securities held to maturity increased by
	$700.3&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2015, primarily due to the acquisition of METR. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, we did not hold any trading securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	68
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The weighted average yields for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	securities are computed on an FTE basis
	using the federal statutory tax rate of 35.0%. The weighted average yields for securities available for sale are based on amortized cost.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For additional
	information relating to investment activity, see Note 4, &#147;Securities&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Deposits and Short-Term Borrowings
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As a bank
	holding company, our primary source of funds is deposits. These deposits are provided by businesses, municipalities and individuals located within the markets served by our Community Banking subsidiary.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Total deposits increased $3.4&nbsp;billion to $16.1&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to December&nbsp;31, 2015, primarily as a result of the
	METR acquisition and Fifth Third branch purchase, combined with an organic increase in transaction accounts, which are comprised of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest-bearing,
</FONT>
	savings and NOW accounts (which includes money market
	deposit accounts). The METR acquisition and Fifth Third branch purchase added $2.3&nbsp;billion and $302.5&nbsp;million in deposits, respectively. The increase in transaction accounts is a result of our ongoing marketing campaigns designed to
	attract new customers to our local approach to banking, combined with higher balances being carried by existing customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Short-term borrowings, made up
	of customer repurchase agreements (also referred to as securities sold under repurchase agreements), FHLB advances, federal funds purchased and subordinated notes, increased to $2.5&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016 from $2.0&nbsp;billion at
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. The composition of short-term
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	69
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	borrowings has changed over this period, as federal funds purchased increased $469.0&nbsp;million as these funds were utilized to support loan growth. Customer repurchase agreements, which are
	sweep accounts with next day maturities utilized by larger commercial customers to earn interest on their funds, increased $46.3&nbsp;million over this same period. FHLB borrowings decreased $65.0&nbsp;million in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following is a summary of selected information relating to certain components of short-term borrowings:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<B>
	At or for the Year Ended December&nbsp;31
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

	For additional information relating to deposits and short-term borrowings, see Note 10, &#147;Deposits&#148; and Note 11,

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Capital Resources
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The access to, and cost of, funding for new business initiatives, including acquisitions, the ability to engage in expanded business activities,
	the ability to pay dividends and the level and nature of regulatory oversight depend, in part, on our capital position.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The assessment of capital
	adequacy depends on a number of factors such as asset quality, liquidity, earnings performance, changing competitive conditions and economic forces. We seek to maintain a strong capital base to support our growth and expansion activities, to provide
	stability to current operations and to promote public confidence.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have an effective shelf registration statement filed with the SEC. Pursuant to this
	registration statement, we may, from time to time, issue and sell in one or more offerings any combination of common stock, preferred stock or debt securities. On October&nbsp;2, 2015, we completed our offering of $100.0&nbsp;million aggregate
	principal amount of 4.875% subordinated notes due in 2025 under this registration statement. The subordinated notes are
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	70
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage71"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	treated as tier 2 capital for regulatory capital purposes. The net proceeds of the debt offering after deducting underwriting discounts and commissions and offering expenses were
	$98.4&nbsp;million. We used the net proceeds from the sale of the subordinated notes for general corporate purposes, which included investments at the holding company level, providing capital to support the growth of FNBPA and our business,
	including the acquisition of METR and the Fifth Third branches.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Capital management is a continuous process with capital plans and stress testing for FNB
	and FNBPA updated at least annually. These capital plans include assessing the adequacy of expected capital levels assuming various scenarios by projecting capital needs for a forecast period of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2-3
</FONT>
	years
	beyond the current year. Both FNB and FNBPA are subject to various regulatory capital requirements administered by federal banking agencies. For additional information, see Note 20, &#147;Regulatory Matters&#148; in the Notes to the Consolidated
	Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report. From time to time, we issue shares initially acquired by us as treasury stock under our various benefit plans. We may continue to grow through acquisitions, which can potentially
	impact our capital position. We may issue additional preferred stock, common stock or subordinated debt in order to maintain our well-capitalized status.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Commitments to extend credit and standby letters of credit do not necessarily represent future cash requirements because while
	the borrower has the ability to draw upon these commitments at any time, these commitments often expire without being drawn upon. Additionally, a significant portion of these commitments can be terminated by FNB. For additional information relating
	to commitments to extend credit and standby letters of credit, see Note 14, &#147;Commitments, Credit Risk and Contingencies&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, which is included in Item 8 of this Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	LIQUIDITY
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our goal in liquidity management is to
	satisfy the cash flow requirements of customers and the operating cash needs of FNB with cost-effective funding. Our Board of Directors has established an Asset/Liability Management Policy in order to guide management in achieving and maintaining
	earnings performance consistent
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	71
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage72"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	with long-term goals, while maintaining acceptable levels of interest rate risk, a &#147;well-capitalized&#148; balance sheet and adequate levels of liquidity. Our Board of Directors has also
	established a Contingency Funding Policy to guide management in addressing stressed liquidity conditions. These policies designate our Asset/Liability Committee (ALCO) as the body responsible for meeting these objectives. The ALCO, which is
	comprised of members of executive management, reviews liquidity on a continuous basis and approves significant changes in strategies that affect balance sheet or cash flow positions. Liquidity is centrally managed on a daily basis by our Treasury
	Department.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	FNBPA generates liquidity from its normal business operations. Liquidity sources from assets include payments from loans and investments, as
	well as the ability to securitize, pledge or sell loans, investment securities and other assets. Liquidity sources from liabilities are generated primarily through the banking offices of FNBPA in the form of deposits and customer repurchase
	agreements. FNB also has access to reliable and cost-effective wholesale sources of liquidity. Short- and long-term funds can be acquired to help fund normal business operations, as well as to serve as contingency funding in the event that we would
	be faced with a liquidity crisis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The principal sources of the parent company&#146;s liquidity are its strong existing cash resources plus dividends it
	receives from its subsidiaries. These dividends may be impacted by the parent&#146;s or its subsidiaries&#146; capital needs, statutory laws and regulations, corporate policies, contractual restrictions, profitability and other factors. In addition,
	FNB, through one of our subsidiaries, regularly issues subordinated notes, which are guaranteed by FNB. Cash on hand at the parent has been managed by various strategies over the last few years.&nbsp;These include strong earnings, increasing
	earnings retention rate&nbsp;and capital actions.&nbsp;On October&nbsp;2, 2015, we issued $100.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 4.875% subordinated debt due in 2025. The net proceeds of the debt offering after deducting underwriting
	discounts and commissions and offering expenses were $98.4&nbsp;million. In 2016, we utilized a portion of the net proceeds from the debt offering to provide $70.0&nbsp;million in capital to support the growth of FNBPA, primarily the METR
	acquisition. As a result, the parent&#146;s cash position decreased $62.3&nbsp;million from $226.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 to $164.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management believes our cash levels are appropriate given the current environment. Two metrics that are used to gauge the adequacy of the parent
	company&#146;s cash position are the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) and Months of Cash on Hand (MCH). The LCR is defined as the sum of cash on hand plus projected cash inflows over the next 12 months divided by projected cash outflows over the next
	12 months. The MCH is defined as the number of months of corporate expenses and dividends that can be covered by the cash on hand. Both metrics have improved versus the prior year end.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The LCR and MCH ratios, as well as subordinated notes data, are presented in the following table:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_30"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="60%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="5%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="5%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="5%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<B>
</B>
	(dollars in thousands)
<B>
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our liquidity position continues to be strong as evidenced by our ability to generate growth in relationship-based accounts.
	Total average deposits totaled $15.4&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and increased $3.2&nbsp;billion, or 26.5%, year over year, due to the acquisition of METR and the Fifth Third branches, as well as organic growth. Average organic growth was
	$887.2&nbsp;million or 7.2% for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-to-date
</FONT>
</FONT>
	period. Organic growth in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-cost
</FONT>
	transaction deposits for 2016 was
	$1.0&nbsp;billion, or 10.5%, led by strong organic growth in average
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-interest
</FONT>
	bearing deposits of $644.9&nbsp;million, or 22.5% , and average savings and NOW of $367.8&nbsp;million, or 5.4%. The strong
	growth in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-cost
</FONT>
	transaction deposits was slightly offset by a decline in average time deposits of $125.5&nbsp;million, or 4.9% for the period on an organic basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	FNBPA had unused wholesale credit availability sources that include the availability to borrow from the FHLB, the FRB, correspondent bank lines and access to
	brokered certificates of deposit. In addition to credit availability,
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	72
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage73"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280128D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	FNBPA also possesses salable unpledged government and agency securities which could be utilized to meet funding needs. The ALCO Policy minimum guideline level for salable unpledged government and
	agency securities is 3.0%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table presents certain information relating to credit availability and salable unpledged securities:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Another metric for measuring liquidity risk is the liquidity gap analysis. The following liquidity gap analysis as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 compares the difference between our cash flows from existing assets and liabilities over future time intervals. Management seeks to limit the size of the liquidity gaps so that sources and uses of funds are reasonably matched
	in the normal course of business. A reasonably matched position lays a better foundation for dealing with additional funding needs during a potential liquidity crisis. The twelve-month cumulative gap to total assets was (3.3)% and (2.6)% as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
